Project Name: Green Book and Contemporary Police Violence
Description: Do counties without Green Book listings (historical hostility to Black travelers) have higher police killing rates? Analysis of 1,080 counties with Fatal Encounters data, lynching records, and ACS demographics. Surprising finding: counties WITH Green Book have MORE killings, driven by urbanization.
Keywords: policing, race, historical discrimination, Green Book, fatal encounters, Jim Crow
Target Journals: American Political Science Review, Journal of Politics

Description: Citizens Police Data Project: FOIA-obtained complaint data for Chicago Police Department spanning 2002-2015. Includes misconduct categories, officer information, and geographic data. Unexplored potential for analyzing complaint patterns and officer accountability.

Project Name: SPLC Hate Groups and Confederate Monuments
Description: Dataset linking SPLC active hate groups (2014) with Confederate monument locations and school data. Potential analysis of historical symbolism and contemporary extremism.
Keywords: hate groups, Confederate monuments, SPLC, political extremism
Target Journals: Journal of Politics, Political Research Quarterly

Description: 844,632 documents from 403 human rights organizations: 26,084 press releases (HRW, Amnesty, ACLU, Freedom House) and 818,548 tweets. Classified by country (136) and UDHR rights categories (18). Sentiment analysis included. Data paper forthcoming; seeking applications.
Keywords: human rights, NGOs, advocacy, press releases, Twitter, naming and shaming

Project Name: Japanese Public Opinion on US-Japan Security
Description: Survey experiment (Nâ‰ˆ1000) on Japanese attitudes toward Belt and Road Initiative, Free and Open Indo-Pacific, and Japan-Korea reconciliation. Key findings: BRI support drops 1/3 SD when framed as military; FOIP support drops 1/4 SD when framed as complementing China; remorse primes increase perceived Japanese remorse.
Keywords: Japan, security, survey experiment, BRI, Indo-Pacific, Korea, reconciliation
Target Journals: International Organization, Journal of Conflict Resolution

Description: Corpus of UN human rights documents (XML format) for text analysis. Research questions: measuring state affinity beyond voting records, correlates of naming and shaming, specificity of HR reports over time. Early-stage project with data collection infrastructure in place.
Keywords: human rights, United Nations, naming and shaming, text analysis, international institutions

Description: When does the public demand increased state respect for human rights? Examining cultural background, economic prosperity, threat perceptions, and status quo challenges. Theoretical framework developed; seeking cross-national survey data or funding for original data collection.
Keywords: human rights, public opinion, political culture, cross-national
Target Journals: Comparative Political Studies, British Journal of Political Science

Project Name: Belarus 2017 Protests: Economic Grievances and Authoritarian Stability
Description: Why did the 2017 'social parasites tax' protests catch regional experts by surprise? Analysis of the most widespread protests in Belarusian history, examining how economic recession eroded tolerance for unpopular policies. Explores interaction between domestic economic conditions and international context (Belarus-Russia tensions, Western rapprochement).
Keywords: Belarus, protests, authoritarianism, economic grievances, collective action, Lukashenko

Project Name: Self-Censorship Under Autocracy: A Survey Experiment with Belarusian Journalists
Description: When do journalists in authoritarian regimes self-censor? Survey experiment design using randomized response technique to measure willingness to report critically on regime. Treatments vary: (1) expected punishment, (2) public support for regime, (3) subscriber impact. Infrastructure ready; seeking funding for implementation.
Keywords: Belarus, journalism, self-censorship, authoritarianism, survey experiment, media freedom
Target Journals: Journal of Politics, Comparative Political Studies

Project Name: Formal vs. Informal Repression: Dissident Punishment in Belarus and Ukraine
Description: Why do some autocrats use courts while others use extrajudicial violence? Original dataset on dissident punishment in Belarus and Ukraine (1991-2004) with interviews of opposition members. Counterintuitive finding: countries with Western ties and independent institutions more likely to use extrajudicial means. Lukashenko imprisoned; Kuchma used informal sanctions.
Keywords: repression, dissidents, authoritarianism, Belarus, Ukraine, courts, extrajudicial violence

Project Name: European Protest Event Data (1980-1995): Francisco Dataset Revival
Description: Reintroducing Ronald Francisco's seminal protest event dataset with modern empirical approaches. 225,000+ coded protest events across 70 country-years covering all of Europe. Variables include action type, protesters, targets, location, issue, arrests, injuries, deaths, property damage. Ready for machine learning, time-series analysis, and cross-national comparison.
Keywords: protest, contentious politics, Europe, event data, collective action, social movements
Target Journals: American Political Science Review, Journal of Politics

Project Name: Dynamics of Contentious Politics: Machine Learning on Francisco Protest Data
Description: Applying modern NLP and machine learning to classify and predict protest dynamics using the Francisco European protest dataset. Potential analyses: protest diffusion patterns, tactical innovation, government response escalation, issue evolution across countries and time.
Keywords: protest, machine learning, NLP, contentious politics, event data, prediction
Target Journals: Political Analysis, Political Science Research and Methods
